texts.label: text
texts.orig: As promised in my earlier post entitled  Kerberos for haters , I've assembled the simplest possible guide to get Kerberos up an running on two CentOS 5 servers.
texts.text: As promised in my earlier post entitled  Kerberos for haters , I've assembled the simplest possible guide to get Kerberos up an running on two CentOS 5 servers.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Also, I don't really  hate  Kerberos. It's a bit of an inside joke with my coworkers who are studying for some of the  RHCA  exams at Rackspace. The additional security provided by Kerberos is quite good but the setup involves a lot of small steps. If you miss one of the steps or if you get something done out of order, you may have to scrap the whole setup and start over unless you can make sense of the errors in the log files. A lot of my dislikes for Kerberos comes from the number of steps required in the setup process and the difficulty in tracking down issues when they crop up.
texts.text: Also, I don't really  hate  Kerberos. It's a bit of an inside joke with my coworkers who are studying for some of the  RHCA  exams at Rackspace. The additional security provided by Kerberos is quite good but the setup involves a lot of small steps. If you miss one of the steps or if you get something done out of order, you may have to scrap the whole setup and start over unless you can make sense of the errors in the log files. A lot of my dislikes for Kerberos comes from the number of steps required in the setup process and the difficulty in tracking down issues when they crop up.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: To complete this guide, you'll need the following:
texts.text: To complete this guide, you'll need the following:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: two CentOS, Red Hat Enterprise Linux or Scientific Linux 5 servers or VM's
texts.text: two CentOS, Red Hat Enterprise Linux or Scientific Linux 5 servers or VM's

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Here's how I plan to name my servers:
texts.text: Here's how I plan to name my servers:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: CRITICAL STEP:  Before getting started, ensure that both systems have their hostnames properly set and both systems have the hostnames and IP addresses of both systems in
texts.text: CRITICAL STEP:  Before getting started, ensure that both systems have their hostnames properly set and both systems have the hostnames and IP addresses of both systems in

texts.label: text
texts.orig: . Your server and client must be able to know the IP and hostname of the other system as well as themselves.
texts.text: . Your server and client must be able to know the IP and hostname of the other system as well as themselves.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: First off, we will need  NIS  working to serve up the user information for our client. Install the NIS server components on the KDC server:
texts.text: First off, we will need  NIS  working to serve up the user information for our client. Install the NIS server components on the KDC server:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Set the NIS domain and set a static port for
texts.text: Set the NIS domain and set a static port for

texts.label: text
texts.orig: to make it easier to firewall off. Edit
texts.text: to make it easier to firewall off. Edit

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Manually set the NIS domain on the KDC server and add it to
texts.text: Manually set the NIS domain on the KDC server and add it to

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[root@kdc ~]# nisdomain EXAMPLE.COM
[root@kdc ~]# echo "domain EXAMPLE.COM server kdc.example.com" >> /etc/yp.conf
texts.text:
[root@kdc ~]# nisdomain EXAMPLE.COM
[root@kdc ~]# echo "domain EXAMPLE.COM server kdc.example.com" >> /etc/yp.conf

texts.label: text
texts.orig: on the KDC server for additional security:
texts.text: on the KDC server for additional security:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Start the NIS server and generate the NIS maps:
texts.text: Start the NIS server and generate the NIS maps:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: I usually like to prepare my iptables rules ahead of time so I ensure that it doesn't derail me later on. Paste this into the KDC's terminal:
texts.text: I usually like to prepare my iptables rules ahead of time so I ensure that it doesn't derail me later on. Paste this into the KDC's terminal:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
iptables -N SERVICES
iptables -I INPUT -j SERVICES
iptables -A SERVICES -p tcp --dport 111 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "rpc"
iptables -A SERVICES -p udp --dport 111 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "rpc"
iptables -A SERVICES -p tcp --dport 808 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "nis"
iptables -A SERVICES -p udp --dport 808 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "nis"
iptables -A SERVICES -p tcp --dport 88 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "kerberos"
iptables -A SERVICES -p udp --dport 88 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "kerberos"
iptables -A SERVICES -p udp --dport 464 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "kerberos"
iptables -A SERVICES -p tcp --dport 749 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "kerberos"
/etc/init.d/iptables save
texts.text:
iptables -N SERVICES
iptables -I INPUT -j SERVICES
iptables -A SERVICES -p tcp --dport 111 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "rpc"
iptables -A SERVICES -p udp --dport 111 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "rpc"
iptables -A SERVICES -p tcp --dport 808 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "nis"
iptables -A SERVICES -p udp --dport 808 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "nis"
iptables -A SERVICES -p tcp --dport 88 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "kerberos"
iptables -A SERVICES -p udp --dport 88 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "kerberos"
iptables -A SERVICES -p udp --dport 464 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "kerberos"
iptables -A SERVICES -p tcp --dport 749 -j ACCEPT -m comment --comment "kerberos"
/etc/init.d/iptables save

texts.label: text
texts.orig: We need our time in sync for Kerberos to work properly. Install NTP on both nodes, start it, and ensure it comes up at boot time:
texts.text: We need our time in sync for Kerberos to work properly. Install NTP on both nodes, start it, and ensure it comes up at boot time:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[root@kdc ~]# yum -y install ntp && chkconfig ntpd on && /etc/init.d/ntpd start
[root@client ~]# yum -y install ntp && chkconfig ntpd on && /etc/init.d/ntpd start
texts.text:
[root@kdc ~]# yum -y install ntp && chkconfig ntpd on && /etc/init.d/ntpd start
[root@client ~]# yum -y install ntp && chkconfig ntpd on && /etc/init.d/ntpd start

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Now we're ready to set up Kerberos. Start by installing some packages on the KDC:
texts.text: Now we're ready to set up Kerberos. Start by installing some packages on the KDC:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: We will need to make some edits to
texts.text: We will need to make some edits to

texts.label: text
texts.orig: on the KDC to set up our KDC realm. Ensure that the
texts.text: on the KDC to set up our KDC realm. Ensure that the

texts.label: text
texts.orig: There's one last configuration file to edit on the KDC! Ensure that
texts.text: There's one last configuration file to edit on the KDC! Ensure that

texts.label: text
texts.orig: We're now ready to make a KDC database to hold our sensitive Kerberos data. Create the database and set a good password which you can remember. This command also stashes your password on the KDC so you don't have to enter it each time you start the KDC:
texts.text: We're now ready to make a KDC database to hold our sensitive Kerberos data. Create the database and set a good password which you can remember. This command also stashes your password on the KDC so you don't have to enter it each time you start the KDC:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: On the KDC, create a principal for the admin user as well as user1 (which we'll create shortly). Also, export the admin details to the kadmind key tab. You'll get some extra output after each one of these commands but I've snipped it to reduce the length of the post.
texts.text: On the KDC, create a principal for the admin user as well as user1 (which we'll create shortly). Also, export the admin details to the kadmind key tab. You'll get some extra output after each one of these commands but I've snipped it to reduce the length of the post.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[root@kdc ~]# kadmin.local
kadmin.local:  addprinc root/admin
kadmin.local:  addprinc user1
kadmin.local:  ktadd -k /var/kerberos/krb5kdc/kadm5.keytab kadmin/admin
kadmin.local:  ktadd -k /var/kerberos/krb5kdc/kadm5.keytab kadmin/changepw
kadmin.local:  exit
texts.text:
[root@kdc ~]# kadmin.local
kadmin.local:  addprinc root/admin
kadmin.local:  addprinc user1
kadmin.local:  ktadd -k /var/kerberos/krb5kdc/kadm5.keytab kadmin/admin
kadmin.local:  ktadd -k /var/kerberos/krb5kdc/kadm5.keytab kadmin/changepw
kadmin.local:  exit

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Let's start the Kerberos KDC and kadmin daemons:
texts.text: Let's start the Kerberos KDC and kadmin daemons:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[root@kdc ~]# /etc/init.d/krb5kdc start; /etc/init.d/kadmin start
[root@kdc ~]# chkconfig krb5kdc on; chkconfig kadmin on
texts.text:
[root@kdc ~]# /etc/init.d/krb5kdc start; /etc/init.d/kadmin start
[root@kdc ~]# chkconfig krb5kdc on; chkconfig kadmin on

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Now that the administration work is done, let's create a principal for our KDC server and stick it in it's keytab:
texts.text: Now that the administration work is done, let's create a principal for our KDC server and stick it in it's keytab:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[root@kdc ~]# kadmin.local
kadmin.local:  addprinc -randkey host/kdc.example.com
kadmin.local:  ktadd host/kdc.example.com
texts.text:
[root@kdc ~]# kadmin.local
kadmin.local:  addprinc -randkey host/kdc.example.com
kadmin.local:  ktadd host/kdc.example.com

texts.label: text
texts.orig: from the KDC server to the client. Hop onto the client server, install the Kerberos client package and add some host principals:
texts.text: from the KDC server to the client. Hop onto the client server, install the Kerberos client package and add some host principals:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[root@client ~]# yum install krb5-workstation
[root@client ~]# kadmin.local
kadmin.local:  addpinc --randkey host/client.example.com
kadmin.local:  ktadd host/kdc.example.com
texts.text:
[root@client ~]# yum install krb5-workstation
[root@client ~]# kadmin.local
kadmin.local:  addpinc --randkey host/client.example.com
kadmin.local:  ktadd host/kdc.example.com

texts.label: text
texts.orig: There aren't any daemons on the client side, so the configuration is pretty much wrapped up there for Kerberos. However, we now need to tell both servers to use Kerberos for auth and your client servers needs to use NIS to get user data.
texts.text: There aren't any daemons on the client side, so the configuration is pretty much wrapped up there for Kerberos. However, we now need to tell both servers to use Kerberos for auth and your client servers needs to use NIS to get user data.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: don't edit the configuration (authconfig got the data from
texts.text: don't edit the configuration (authconfig got the data from

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: enter your NIS domain (EXAMPLE.COM) and NIS server (kdc.example.com or 192.168.250.2)
texts.text: enter your NIS domain (EXAMPLE.COM) and NIS server (kdc.example.com or 192.168.250.2)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: don't edit the Kerberos configuration (authconfig got the data from
texts.text: don't edit the Kerberos configuration (authconfig got the data from

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Got NIS problems?  If the NIS connection stalls on the client, ensure that you have the iptables rules present on the KDC that we added near the beginning of this guide. Also, if you forgot to add  both  hosts to  both  servers'
texts.text: Got NIS problems?  If the NIS connection stalls on the client, ensure that you have the iptables rules present on the KDC that we added near the beginning of this guide. Also, if you forgot to add  both  hosts to  both  servers'

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Let's make our test user on the KDC.  Don't add this user to the client  — we'll get the user information via NIS and authenticate via Kerberos shortly. We'll also rebuild our NIS maps after adding the user:
texts.text: Let's make our test user on the KDC.  Don't add this user to the client  — we'll get the user information via NIS and authenticate via Kerberos shortly. We'll also rebuild our NIS maps after adding the user:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: On the client, see if you can get the password hash for the user1 account via NIS:
texts.text: On the client, see if you can get the password hash for the user1 account via NIS:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[root@client ~]# ypcat -d EXAMPLE.COM -h kdc.example.com passwd | grep user1
user1:$1$sUlSTlCv$riK5El3z8N4y.mi5Fe3Q60:500:500::/home/user1:/bin/bash
texts.text:
[root@client ~]# ypcat -d EXAMPLE.COM -h kdc.example.com passwd | grep user1
user1:$1$sUlSTlCv$riK5El3z8N4y.mi5Fe3Q60:500:500::/home/user1:/bin/bash

texts.label: text
texts.orig: You can see why NIS isn't a good way to authenticate users. Someone could easily pull the hash for any account and brute force the hash on their own server. Go back to the KDC and lock out the user account:
texts.text: You can see why NIS isn't a good way to authenticate users. Someone could easily pull the hash for any account and brute force the hash on their own server. Go back to the KDC and lock out the user account:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Go back to the client and try to pull the password hash now:
texts.text: Go back to the client and try to pull the password hash now:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[root@client ~]# ypcat -d EXAMPLE.COM -h kdc.example.com passwd | grep user1
user1:!!:500:500::/home/user1:/bin/bash
texts.text:
[root@client ~]# ypcat -d EXAMPLE.COM -h kdc.example.com passwd | grep user1
user1:!!:500:500::/home/user1:/bin/bash

texts.label: text
texts.orig: On the plus side, the user's password hash is now gone. On the negative side, you've just prevented this user from logging in locally or via NIS. Don't worry, the user can log in via Kerberos now. Let's prepare a home directory on the client for the user:
texts.text: On the plus side, the user's password hash is now gone. On the negative side, you've just prevented this user from logging in locally or via NIS. Don't worry, the user can log in via Kerberos now. Let's prepare a home directory on the client for the user:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Note: In a real-world scenario, you'd probably want to export this user's home directory via NFS so they didn't get a different home directory on every server.
texts.text: Note: In a real-world scenario, you'd probably want to export this user's home directory via NFS so they didn't get a different home directory on every server.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: While you're still on the client, try to log into the client via the user. Use the password that you used when you created the user1 principal on the KDC.
texts.text: While you're still on the client, try to log into the client via the user. Use the password that you used when you created the user1 principal on the KDC.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[root@client ~]# ssh user1@localhost
user1@localhost's password:
[user1@client ~]$ whoami
user1
texts.text:
[root@client ~]# ssh user1@localhost
user1@localhost's password:
[user1@client ~]$ whoami
user1

texts.label: text
texts.orig: List your Kerberos tickets and you should see one for your user principal:
texts.text: List your Kerberos tickets and you should see one for your user principal:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[user1@client ~]$ klist
Ticket cache: FILE:/tmp/krb5cc_500_fCKPnZ
Default principal: user1@EXAMPLE.COM

Valid starting     Expires            Service principal
02/05/12 14:18:53  02/06/12 00:18:53  krbtgt/EXAMPLE.COM@EXAMPLE.COM
	renew until 02/05/12 14:18:53
texts.text:
[user1@client ~]$ klist
Ticket cache: FILE:/tmp/krb5cc_500_fCKPnZ
Default principal: user1@EXAMPLE.COM

Valid starting     Expires            Service principal
02/05/12 14:18:53  02/06/12 00:18:53  krbtgt/EXAMPLE.COM@EXAMPLE.COM
	renew until 02/05/12 14:18:53

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Your KDC should have a couple of lines in its
texts.text: Your KDC should have a couple of lines in its

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
Feb 05 14:18:53 kdc.example.com krb5kdc[4694](info): AS_REQ (12 etypes {18 17 16 23 1 3 2 11 10 15 12 13}) 192.168.250.3: ISSUE: authtime 1328473133, etypes {rep=16 tkt=16 ses=16}, user1@EXAMPLE.COM for krbtgt/EXAMPLE.COM@EXAMPLE.COM
Feb 05 14:18:53 kdc.example.com krb5kdc[4694](info): TGS_REQ (7 etypes {18 17 16 23 1 3 2}) 192.168.250.3: ISSUE: authtime 1328473133, etypes {rep=16 tkt=18 ses=18}, user1@EXAMPLE.COM for host/client.example.com@EXAMPLE.COM
texts.text:
Feb 05 14:18:53 kdc.example.com krb5kdc[4694](info): AS_REQ (12 etypes {18 17 16 23 1 3 2 11 10 15 12 13}) 192.168.250.3: ISSUE: authtime 1328473133, etypes {rep=16 tkt=16 ses=16}, user1@EXAMPLE.COM for krbtgt/EXAMPLE.COM@EXAMPLE.COM
Feb 05 14:18:53 kdc.example.com krb5kdc[4694](info): TGS_REQ (7 etypes {18 17 16 23 1 3 2}) 192.168.250.3: ISSUE: authtime 1328473133, etypes {rep=16 tkt=18 ses=18}, user1@EXAMPLE.COM for host/client.example.com@EXAMPLE.COM

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The first line shows that the client asked for a Authentication Server Request (AS REQ) and the second line shows that the client then asked for a Ticket Granting Server Request (TGS REQ). In layman's terms, the client first asked for a ticket-granting ticket (TGT) so it could authenticate to other services. When it actually tried to log in via
texts.text: The first line shows that the client asked for a Authentication Server Request (AS REQ) and the second line shows that the client then asked for a Ticket Granting Server Request (TGS REQ). In layman's terms, the client first asked for a ticket-granting ticket (TGT) so it could authenticate to other services. When it actually tried to log in via

texts.label: text
texts.orig: it asked for a ticket (and received it).
texts.text: it asked for a ticket (and received it).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: From here, the sky's the limit. Another popular implementation of Kerberos is encrypted NFSv4. You can even go crazy and use  Kerberos with apache .
texts.text: From here, the sky's the limit. Another popular implementation of Kerberos is encrypted NFSv4. You can even go crazy and use  Kerberos with apache .

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Let me know if you have any questions about this post or if you spot any errors. With this many steps, there's bound to be a typo or two in this guide. Keep in mind that there are some obvious spots for network-level and service-level security improvements. This guide was intended to give you the basics and it doesn't cover all of the security implications involved with a Kerberos implementation.
texts.text: Let me know if you have any questions about this post or if you spot any errors. With this many steps, there's bound to be a typo or two in this guide. Keep in mind that there are some obvious spots for network-level and service-level security improvements. This guide was intended to give you the basics and it doesn't cover all of the security implications involved with a Kerberos implementation.
